ygData.subject: Re: Species stagnation
ygData.msgSnippet: Hey Derek, It s probably good advice to not get stuck on the little things.  It s also very interesting to hear that you have had success with absolutely no

Hey Derek,

It's probably good advice to not get stuck on the little things.  It's
also very interesting to hear that you have had success with
absolutely no sterilization.

The reason I'm asking all these questions is that I am trying to
evolve my agents on a particular task at the moment and it is just not
getting there.  If I evolve them for 1000 generations, it just won't
get there.  It got the solution once but I've since added another
input so the previous genome is invalid to the project.

Thus I am trying to figure out how to avoid this stagnation as I am
staring at a population of 500 genomes that simply are not converging
on the correct answer.

Quickly: I am evolving a cat to chase a mouse around a simple 2D maze
(no dead ends, 16 blocks evenly spaced in the maze to make connected
corridors).  I am trying to evolve a cat that learns to remember where
he last saw the mouse, so he can go there and continue the search. 
But it just won't converge.  If he sees the mouse he can catch it just
fine but as soon as the mouse goes out of view, it collapses.  I've
used incremental learning to teach one thing at a time but when I
setup the out-of-sight mouse experiment, it just won't converge.

If the solution doesn't lie in correcting these niggly bits of NEAT
then I'll start re-thinking the scenario I'm using to test in. 
Perhaps no matter how I fiddle with the parameters of NEAT it still
won't converge.

Mike

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Derek James <djames@g...> wrote:
> On Wed, 30 Mar 2005 18:16:31 -0000, gerbopel <redcrocodile@h...> wrote:
> > There is _certainly_ no shortage of options, but I do feel that I'm
> > basically just throwing darts at a board deciding what to try next and
> > each "attempt" takes me a day or so to fully test out.
> > 
> > That's brutal.
> 
> Mike, you've noted that you've already performed some successful runs
> in XOR and your domain.  Philip and I reimplemented NEAT in Java (ANJI
> is our implementation), and we learned quite a bit from this process. 
> Even though Ken did a great job explaining his algorithm in his
> initial paper, it is nearly impossible to cover every implementation
> detail.  We had LOTS of questions for Ken, and he helped immensely.
> 
> But one of the more important things I think we got out of it is that
> many of the implementation details are simply not crucial.  I think
> Ken did a good job with the ablation experiments to verify the
> important aspects of NEAT, but we've found that as along as it
> includes the main components, some of the more detailed implementation
> aspects don't really impact performance all that much.
> 
> You might want to go back and read some of the messages around #1205,
> where we indicate that with ANJI, we didn't implement stagnation
> penalties at all!  We still haven't done so.  We also don't cap the
> number of species in the population (I'm not sure if the
> implementation you're working on does this).  And there is quite a bit
> of turnover in the population, and older species dying off as they're
> replaced by fitter ones.
> 
> And we've had very good success in all but the most difficult domains
> we've tried.
> 
> Again, if you're saying that the algorithm is working reasonably well,
> I wouldn't get hung up on trying to implement NEAT down to every last
> detail.  It's a pretty robust algorithm, and as long as you've got the
> core, you'll probably do fine.
> 
> Derek
